topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554ad6e06368725ce09c0f00#post_554ad6e06368725ce09c0f00
Yep.
In Asia, it's both religious and tradition that becomes the obstacles. Though, it's tradition that's more influencial. Some countries can give you a death sentence for such actions. Others either put you in jail or a psyche ward. Which is kinda scary if you ask me.
topics.author: 4fe1b9f47f123b13df002976

You know, in my country, same-sex marriage has been legalized for a time... And I haven't even ask my best pal from college if he married his boyfriend, yet. One distances himself and...

Well, he's only 28, and people here tend to marry when they're about 30, so...

It's going to be a tough fight for the gay rights movement in asia, but fighting against tradition is way more easy than fighting against religious beliefs.

I doubt same sex marriage will ever be legal in the majority of the middle east or africa in comparison.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554ad94d6368720420020100#post_554ad94d6368720420020100
Middle East will take years before any kind of movement like this would start or even make an impact.
You start doing things like these and they send armies to take you down. You're basically a terrorist to them for telling people about same-sex marriage. They will do whatever they can to shut your mouth and forcefully assimilate you.
